channel.title: The inner core: City within a city
channel.description:
A documentary series on urban conditions for residents of the Inner Core of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: The inner core: City within a city

item.title: Adjustment for Teens
item.description: An interview with one of the teenage residents of the inner city, focusing on his problems of adjustment as a relative newcomer from the South and dealing with some of his past problems and future aspirations.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Part 4 of 4, reel 1: Pride and prejudice: an American heritage
item.description: This program is the last of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. In the next hour we'll look at some of the pride and prejudice we live by, and, through the comments of some of the people of Milwaukee's inner core, we'll examine that ugly insult we call prejudice.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Part 1 of 4, reel 2
item.description: This program is the first of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. This program visits Lincoln High: drab on the outside, amazingly well-equipped inside; met a principal respected by almost all his students; heard teachers praised and condemned; and learned about problems specific only to Lincoln and problems common to all schools.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Part 4 of 4, reel 2: Pride and prejudice: an American heritage
item.description: This program is the last of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. In the next hour we'll look at some of the pride and prejudice we live by, and, through the comments of some of the people of Milwaukee's inner core, we'll examine that ugly insult we call prejudice.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Shopping in the Inner City
item.description: Interview with Milwaukee County Extension workers Barbara Rice and Geneva Erickson on the problem of shopping in the inner city and kinds of programs needed by inner city homemakers.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Social Programs
item.description: An interview with Jimmii Givings and David Chancer of Milwaukee's Northcott Neighborhood House--a social services agency--dealing with the kinds of programs necessary to upgrade the inner city and touching on the issue of violence.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Part 1 of 4, reel 1
item.description: This program is the first of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. This program visits Lincoln High: drab on the outside, amazingly well-equipped inside; met a principal respected by almost all his students; heard teachers praised and condemned; and learned about problems specific only to Lincoln and problems common to all schools.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Part 3 of 4, reel 1: The relationship between the people and the police
item.description: This program is the third of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. During the next hour you'll hear a montage of citizen opinion on the quality of their police department; excerpts from the Milwaukee Community Relations Social Development Commission hearings on police brutality; and an interview with Mr. Richard Artisan, the former community relations specialist for the Milwaukee Fire and Police Commission.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Part 2 of 4, reel 1: The anatomy of a gyp
item.description: This program is the second of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. The problems of the consumer are not limited to the ghetto, but they are magnified there. Gypsters prey on residents because their low incomes make it difficult if not impossible to receive credit from legitimate merchants.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Employment and Leadership
item.description: Interview with Wesley Scott of the Milwaukee Urban League dealing with employment and leadership in the inner city.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: If They'd Just Admit the Problem
item.description: If They'd Just Admit the Problem. A montage of comments of inner city residents as they examine what they consider to be one of their most serious problems: condition and quality of their schools.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Housing, Welfare and Employment
item.description: An interview with one of the community workers in Milwaukee's Inner Core focusing on the problems of housing, welfare, and employment and featuring a discussion of welfare recipients and case workers.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Inner City Development Project
item.description: Six advisory board and staff members of the Inner City Development Project on relationships between inner city residents and police, welfare dept., etc
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Mass Media and Urban Turbulence
item.description: In the spring of 1968 a conference on mass media and its coverage of urban turbulence and race relations was held at Wingspread, the conference center of the Johnson Foundation in Racine, Wisconsin. Two of the participants were Singer Buchanan of Eastern Michigan University and Stanley Donner of the University of Texas. Between two of the formal sessions they met and talked with Ralph Johnson of WHA radio.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Let's Look at Prejudice
item.description: Let's Look at Prejudice. Dr. Ernest Spaights of U. of Wisconsin-Milwaukee on the roots of prejudice and how to combat it in our personal lives.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Our Neighbor: The Rat
item.description: Our Neighbor: The Rat. Problems caused by rats, the neighbor nobody wants.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: To Be a Man
item.description: To Be a Man. Two inner city homemakers discuss problems of the African American male in his role as family man and his search to maintain his pride and masculinity in what can be an essentially matriarchal family.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: A House to Live In
item.description: A House to Live In. An exploration of inner city residents' opinions concerning housing, renter-landlord relations, public housing, urban renewal, and open housing.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Homemaking in the Inner City
item.description: Interview with Arlene Miller and Joyce Hardy, home economists who work in the inner city. Addresses problems of homemaking in the inner city and the problem of credit.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Part 2 of 4, reel 2: The anatomy of a gyp
item.description: This program is the second of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. The problems of the consumer are not limited to the ghetto, but they are magnified there. Gypsters prey on residents because their low incomes make it difficult if not impossible to receive credit from legitimate merchants.
item.dc:creator: Johnson, Ralph
item.dc:subject: Wisconsin

item.title: Part 3 of 4, reel 2: The relationship between the people and the police
item.description: This program is the third of four drawn from a special week of broadcasting focusing on the problems of Milwaukee's inner core. During the next hour you'll hear a montage of citizen opinion on the quality of their police department; excerpts from the Milwaukee Community Relations Social Development Commission hearings on police brutality; and an interview with Mr. Richard Artisan, the former community relations specialist for the Milwaukee Fire and Police Commission.
